Topic.Title: If you build it, they will come

Message.Msg: Yahoo's information architecture is very messy, so I will just respond to the header in this thread. Someone asked what might be Tegra's FY 2014 'revenue (year ending January 2014, almost equivalent to CY 2013 revenue with a different ending month), the research note by Hans Mosesmann provided an approximate answer: $764 million, vs $540 in the prior year (from my memory, but in the right ballpark). It is not clear whether NVIDIA management gave Hans this information, he arrived at it based on Raymond James's models. Not bad at all considering that it could be the low end of a wide range. In the same article Mosesmann suggested that the breakeven point for Nvidia Tegra would be below $1 billion. We should know how soon NV could reach that level by the end of the year, or before. One of the focal point of concern right now is the lack of visibility re. NV's new offerings. As Mosesmann cleared stated, all greenfield products are backend loaded - the uptake path is never a straight line. Folks who want both the stability and growth prospects at every time point should remember that nVIDIA doesn't sell laundry detergents: you can't have both within a short time span; however, over a longer period of time, the leaps and stalls may be smoothed out and, yes, you could have both by viewing it longitudinally.

Message.Title: Snapdragon S800 Antutu benchmarks leaked: 32146 (vs Tegra 4: 36000+)
Message.Msg: At the moment, only the ZTE Grand Memo was announced as the first device that powered by the Snapdragon 800 quad-core processor. How fast is this Snapdragon 800 Series processor? Qualcomm said that it has 75% improvement from the Snapdragon S4 Pro. So you can imagine the performance even it is just a quad-core processor. A device with the model number of MSM8974 that clocked up to 2.3GHz was spotted at AnTuTu Benchmark result. Basically the MSM8974 is a processor of Snapdragon 800 Series. The 2.3GHz Snapdragon 800 MSM8974 scores 32,146 points at the AnTuTu Benchmark result. Please remind that the 32,146 points were belonging to the a prototype device that is yet to finalize the software development. So the points could be higher if the Snapdragon 800 processor is in a developed device. For the AnTuTu Benchmark results of other processors, Snapdragon 600 scores about 23,000 points, Samsung Exynos 5 Octa scores about 26,000 points, the NVIDIA Tegra 4 scores about 36,000 points and Intel Clover Trail+processor scores about 27,000 points. The HTC One and LG Optimus G Pro are the devices with Snapdragon 600, Samsung Galaxy S4 with Exynos 5 Octa and Lenovo Ideaphone K900 with Intel Clover Trail+ processor. SOURCE: gsminsiderDOTcom/2013/03/24/snapdragon-800-msm8974-antutu-benchmark-result-leaks-scores-more-than-32000-points/

Topic.Title: Chinese Allwinner selling its quad core chips for $10. Tegra is done.

Message.Msg: Most of the press stories are going out with a "under $20" price on the Allwinner quad core. Presumably that pricing is capped by the Tegra 3, which may still have a performance edge. Allwinner may have cost issues dropping it to $10. ARMH has been telling investors that the A7 carries a much higher royalty payment due to the sophisticated design, the GPU is license isn't cheap, and the dual channel memory controller has a higher area and package cost than a single channel design. Part of the die area cost is offset by using a smaller L2 cache. Despite being a lean design firm, Allwinner can't sell these things at cost/COGS. They must have at least 50% gross margin to cover design risk and production risk. Plus if they intend to become a market leader, they'll have to start investing in device drivers. I do find it interesting that they chose a Tegra-like 4+1 energy-saver core design, instead of big.LITTLE. That lets Allwinner use the mature Tegra 2/3, rather than spending money developing the still-experimental big.LITTLE OS support.

Topic.Title: Chinese Allwinner selling its quad core chips for $10. Tegra is done.

Message.Msg: "I do find it interesting that they chose a Tegra-like 4+1 energy-saver core design, instead of big.LITTLE." Actually the energy-saver core is a modern view to bigLITTLE... The energy-saver core is still an A15, but designed to operate at slower speeds... NVidia found it more optimal to design a cache, memory, and interfaces to one type of CPU than to optimize to two different CPUs...

Topic.Title: Snapdragon S800 Antutu benchmarks leaked: 32146 (vs Tegra 4: 36000+)

Message.Msg: Ashraf, I think you might be misinterpreting how the power is used on T4 because there have been reference tablets and phones with the T4 chip inside going back to MWC. T3 was workable for smart phones and as I understand it the T4 was not intended exclusively for tablets, chromebooks and/or 'consoles'. The way the A15 cores are used is critical to the power consumption and I think some of us are falling into an assumption that the 4+1 still works the same way it did with T3. I don't think simply seeing it as 5W adequately describes how the power envelope is managed. In any case, we'll know soon enough.

Topic.Title: Snapdragon S800 Antutu benchmarks leaked: 32146 (vs Tegra 4: 36000+)

Message.Msg: My take is that the quoted performance numbers are just peak performance. As Nvidia has stated in many cases it is about getting the job done as fast as possible and then ASAP go to sleep. Performing the task fast(er) and hence going to sleep state faster can be better for battery life and end user experience. But, with those numbers Nvidia could choose to adjust the frequency if better for smartphones and still be competitive. /Take care Frank. P.S. I appreciate your articles from SA and your more balanced view of things but often your advice/conclusions seems very attached to near term events rather than the bigger story unfolding. What audience do you intend for your SA articles?

This server strength appears somewhat broad-based, covering Cloud / direct as well as more traditional Enterprise customers. While a positive for VLTR (VLTR) 1Q trends, our LT concerns remain. Message.Title: "AMD builds a game console monopoly"
Message.Msg: "AMD has quietly gained control of the game consoles currently shipping (with the exception of the PS3), and the company recently confirmed it will be providing the core technology for Sony's upcoming PS4." ... "Wrapping Up: AMDâ€™s Not So Secret Advantage However, the not so secret advantage in doing this is that graphically, AMD will basically own the high performance gaming market because developers will feel more comfortable writing to AMDâ€™s unique graphics capabilities once they exist across all the game systems and in PCs. Now because games are increasingly portable between PCs and consoles, this should give them a competitive advantage in the PC gaming market as well that theyâ€™ll surely exploit. You see, it isnâ€™t always the fastest or most powerful product that wins, but it may be the one that is most efficiently utilized. Simply put, this can result in more performance for the buck and buyers, either those building consoles or PCs, are interested in products with the best value because those are the ones consumers often chase. AMD quietly has moved into a position where it could dominate all but portable gaming. And, should they eventually target that, theyâ€™ll come in with the advantage of dominating another market first. I guess AMD has decided it doesn't want to be an underdog anymore." Source: TGDaily

Topic.Title: "AMD builds a game console monopoly"

Message.Msg: I was thinking more along the lines that Sony games, tend to just stay on the console, while Microsoft exclusives eventually get ported to the PC, like Halo, Gears of War etc. Following this, two things are clear. 1. The more commonly ported games for Xbox, which had AMD graphics, did not make a differnece to the fact that Nvidia is the top provider of high end PC gaming graphics. 2. The less-none commonly ported games for the PS, shouldn't make a difference for high end graphics. IE, AMD isn't going to gain much ground in high end PC gaming graphics simply because they are in consoles.

Message.Title: Project Shield's unannounced details...when would they be released?
Message.Msg: Somet chatters PAX EAST indicated that the pricing of Project Shield has been decided on internally at NVIDIA. We may hear about it along with other unannounced details at E3 in early June. Gaming journalists think the pricing will be competitive within the context of profitability. NVIDIA's marketing department should be well-conditioned to fine-gauge the price points after years of intense competition vs AMD in graphic cards. And June is also a crowed months for the release/demo/update of other gaming devices such as OUYA, Razer Edge Pro, GameStick, PS4, next-gen Xbox and "Steam Box" - not all of them are actual releases, of course, but you are gonna hear some thunderous noises.

Topic.Title: Snapdragon S800 Antutu benchmarks leaked: 32146 (vs Tegra 4: 36000+)

Message.Msg: Frank, I understand that it is an unofficial convention (ref. Anandtech) that benchmarks comparisons were made at clock speeds allowing each chip/device's highest claimed HD resolution. The voltages may be different for each chip/devices being compared, but that is a fair way of treating it. I read about this in several of Anandtech articles. In my lead post for this thread, S800 was tested at 2.3GHz, I think the performance numbers for Tegra 4 was obtained at no higher than 2.3GHz.

Topic.Title: Project Shield's unannounced details...when would they be released?

Message.Msg: I think NVIDIA marketing got a good feeling at Pax East re. how well Project Shield was received, and how much serious gamers are willing to pay....this may have sealed their decision on price points for Shield. I've speculated all along that the initial targeted adoptors for PS will likely be the serious and semi-serious gamers who also own a GTX 6xx graphic card, not for the J seven-pack crowd who comb the basement of Walmart for bargains.
